title: Labour would negotiate fresh EU trade plan to protect Nissan if Theresa May fails to get deal
text:

A future Labour government could negotiate a new trade deal with the EU to protect businesses such as Nissan , Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has revealed. 
Speaking to the Chronicle, Mr Corbyn said Nissan needed a tariff-free deal to allow it to export cars for sale in EU countries and to buy parts from EU suppliers. 
And if the Government took the UK out of the EU without such a deal, Labour would re-open negotiations. 
The carmaker, which has a major plant in Sunderland, has warned that it could lose £500 million a year if it has to pay tariffs. 
Prime Minister Theresa May has warned that “no deal for Britain is better than a bad deal for Britain”, raising the prospect of the UK leaving the EU without a trade deal. This would mean falling back on World Trade Organisation rules, which are likely to mean tariffs of 10% on vehicles made in the UK and exported to EU countries. Stephen Martin was asked about special Brexit assurances given to manufacturer Nissan (Photo: Owen Humphreys/PA Wire) 
Mr Corbyn said: “Nissan have made it clear, as have every other motor manufacturer, that their supply lines is in Europe as well as in Britain and their sales are in Europe as well as in Britain.” 
He added: “Tariff free access to Europe is absolutely essential 
“I hope we will get an agreement on tariff free access, because if you trade on World Trade Organisation rules then you are looking at a 10% tariff. 
“So our policy would be to press for that and to try to force the government in to that position, by whatever we do in Parliament as well as the campaigns we mount.” 
However, he said if Labour came in to power when the UK had left the EU without such an agreement, he would try to negotiate one. Read More 
“Now, if we get to the point of a Labour government with no tarfiff-free access, we would immediately try to negotiate one, possibly on a sector-by-sector basis in extremis.
